So -- it is relevant that I have not-so-great eyesight -- I thought that the symbol after 1A was a üéÑaka a Christmas tree; that the other symbols of similar shape were otherwise-colored Christmas trees; and the various round shapes were üå≥ aka round-topped trees. Why the trees were blue as well as red and yellow and green, I had no idea, but I figured it would become clear as I did the puzzle. 

It did not.  Why are trees going to parties? Or, more accurately, /how/ are trees going to parties???

So I come to the column, and the header image is of what looks at first glance to be ping pong paddles üèì   "Aha," I says, "it's multicolored Christmas trees and multicolored paddles / racquets. That ... makes even less sense??"

Finally I pulled out a magnifier and determined the symbols were, er, party hats and balloons. üéà Which connects better to the party theme I guess... üòÇ
Are party hats and balloons associated with SQUARE DANCEs and BOX SOCIALs?  Are there really gatherings called CELL RECEPTIONS or is it just a play on words (uniquely, among the themed answers)?

PLot turned into PLAt (well, maybe that could be right, right?) and finally settled into PLAN when finally realized I did indeed know what that veil was. A fine puzzle that I would have enjoyed more if the symbols weren‚Äôt so small on my iPad mini.

Aww I now feel a bit disappointed that I raced through this one on New Year's Eve Eve, instead of savouring it on the proper day. Almost got my personal best for a Wednesday, so that's something nice.

apropos of nothing current, my expedition through the archives  has yielded more encounters with ezersky puzzles, a setter whose name i invoked a month or two ago in reference to the pleasure of his minis and which elicited several grumbles in this community with respect to his maxis.
i will not speak straight-up ill of any setter.  their brand of clever creativity is largely opaque to me and i admire it greatly.
but i will say i now understand the grumbles.
there is elegant, metaphoric, precision difficulty and there is coarse, literal, pratfall difficulty in the world of cruciverbiage (should be a word).
for me someone like david kwong embodies the former.
i leave it to the reader to complete the comparison.

I think a grammar lesson is needed for the setters. You always incorrectly pluralize single letters with an apostrophe (for example, today's Mini:"The O's [sic] in XOXO". You are normally meticulous to a fault, which makes this obvious error particularly jarring!
Re 65A, I believe yen is a noun, not a verb. If so, the clue should have been "a hankering," not "hanker (for)."

Nevermind.

Had I remembered AGORA more quickly, I‚Äôd have not taken nearly an hour to finish.  But I stubbornly refused to look anything up today.

AGORA is like EDAM and the more common EPEE, ORCA, EEL, X-based words etc‚Ä¶ words that I‚Äôve learned are frequent as fill.  

Agoura Hills, a city near me, got me to guess AGORA.  That triggered completion; had to unwind tic and tsa (guesses for XIN and FBI).

And of course the city has absolutely nothing to do with the Greek marketplace.  But to learn that, I discovered the connection between Alice Coltrane and Doja Cat, the latter another crossword fill answer.  Now that is the kind of useless trivia I live for.

I did not find this to be, as @Sam wrote, "a delightfully festive solve." First, the little party icons were just there to force me to print my paper copy using more ink, since only the newspaper version was displayed. Unless I'm missing something, they serve no real purpose.

XES IN, followed by the improbable REACHED IN? And I never heard of a BOX SOCIAL. Maybe that's on me, but I don't think it's in common parlance. CELL RECEPTION is oddly not a gathering, so it didn't fit the theme the way the other did. The answer for Book Reviewer was also a stretch, since CPAs review the books, plural. IDLE CHAT is another answer that, though it may appear in a dictionary, is something that no one says. It's IDLE CHATTER. 

The revealer was easy enough to come by, but I was saddened to have this be the final puzzle of the year. It was a total slog that fell flat on its face, IMO.

Suffering from memory loss should be amnestic, not amnesic. I realize the latter probably has some common use, but I‚Äôd stake out the position that it needs to be done away with in favor of the former.

So I think¬†the drawings are teensy tiny Christmas trees and teensy tiny New Year's balls, but I can't be sure from the newspaper edition.¬†¬†

Next step:¬† Figure out if they will affect or impede how I fill in the grid.

Big sigh of relief: They don't seem to affect it one iota.¬† Followed by a big sigh of disappointment:¬† If they're not doing¬†anything, then why the bleep are they there?

Beats me.

The themers seem to be circumscribed places (like in a crossword square) where people gather.¬† A theme that would be made better without all the extraneous¬†drawings, as far as I'm concerned.

1A made me think it was going to be a "K" rebus.¬† I've never heard of a RAM truck -- only a MACK truck.¬† I was able to fit in MAC, "confirmed" by MPM (miles per minute!) and waited to see why the thing that looked like a Christmas tree was, in fact, a K.¬† Only it wasn't.

As far as I'm concerned, this would be the same puzzle-solving experience without the tiny little drawings.¬† Only better.

I‚Äôm EDIE CENA, CHAIR of the SQUARE DANCE.  I‚Äôm here to brag about my fascinating guests.

First and foremost, LIBERACE, freshly MANSCAPED and looking svelte from months of AVID adherence to a NO CARB PLAN.  He was stunning in DIOR.  I thought, ‚ÄúAMORE di amore!‚Äù

We were graced by ALI ADAB, the most prominent of the EMIRS in attendance, along with their wives in NIQABs.

Then there was Milli Ami, the life of every PARTY, who so enjoyed the XIN, (or is it Zin?) that she began chanting VIVE LE ROI, understood by no one but enjoyed by all.

REN YEN was there, a Chinese diplomat and a CPA, but hardly a stick in the MUD.  He GETS COMFY in any room.

Our musical guest was rap group ‚ÄúSTEALTH PERPS RPM‚Äù (no ‚ÄúThe‚Äù), of you TUBE fame, accompanied by their pet MACAW named MINI, and their manger PAPA BEAR.

Of some concern was FBI agent, TED TRENT, a sometimes AMNESIC.  He REACHed INto his cold case files and saw that ‚ÄúYEN REN‚Äù was an international spy who he confused with our guest, REN YEN. 

I could go on about how TRENT SET A TRAP, BLOCKed CELL RECEPTION, but fortunately for you dear reader, there is a word limit.

This completes my first perfect calendar year! I started doing the NYT crossword with a few friends at lunchtime in high school back in the 1970s when Eugene T Maleska was the editor. Kids, in the olden days the crossword didn‚Äôt gradually get harder throughout the week (that was one of the best later innovations by Will Shortz), so you never knew what you were going to get. And you had to wait until the next day to check your work (no happy music). Throughout my working career, I would do the puzzle with small groups of colleagues. I am a social solver who really enjoys the interaction and conversation that crossword solving elicits. Now that I am retired it‚Äôs just me and my wife doing the puzzle together every evening. Of course we do Wordle, Spelling Bee, Connections, and Strands too. My Dad lived next door to the starting point in the 1970's.  You had to be either in your home by 6 pm on Dec 31st, or not get in again until afternoon on Jan 1.
